Award.AwardTitle: CEDAR: Radar and Optical Observations of Enhanced Ion Acoustic Lines and Associated Auroral Fine Structure
Award.AbstractNarration: The scientific objective of this project is to combine radar, optical and satellite data to investigate and characterize the occurrence of Naturally Enhanced Ion Acoustic Lines (NEIALs) with coincident auroral fine structures and to provide insight to their possible generation mechanisms. To accomplish this goal, the project will make use of common-volume observations of the nighttime auroral ionosphere with ground-based imagers and the Poker Flat Incoherent Scatter Radar (PFISR). In situ measurements will be made by the Japanese Reimei satellite which will pass once per night, near magnetic midnight, within the all-sky camera field of view (FOV). The observations will take place during the three moon down periods in early 2009 (mid-January through early-April), and one of the moon down periods in early 2010. PFISR observations of NEIALs have raised new questions regarding their occurrence in relation to specific auroral forms. The enhanced returns were found to occur in the dark regions immediately adjacent to thin auroral arc structures and to have altitude propagation at or near the Alfven speed. They are also found to occur near the poleward edge of the large-scale auroral features. Recent observations have found NEIALs to be associated with very dynamic, small-scale auroral arcs, indicative of Alfvenically accelerated electron precipitation. NEIALs in the PFISR data are observed with matching morphology and overlapping parameters as are the broad-band extremely low-frequency (BBELF) waves that are seen with satellites and rockets. These observations suggest connections between NEIALs and BBELF and Alfven waves. The understanding of NEIAL generation mechanisms is a beneficial addition to the incoherent scatter radar community, partly because the presence of NEIALs prevents the application of the normal fitting procedure used to derive the plasma parameters from the radar spectra. Also, NEIALs can be used as a means to study processes occurring in the ionosphere that would not otherwise be obtainable from ISR data. If NEIALs can be linked to specific types of wave activity, instabilities, or electron distributions, then ISRs provide a ground-based method to study when and where they occur.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main purpose of this project was to investigate the relationship between specific anomalous returns in radar data, which are of geophysical origin, and the auroral structures that coincide with them in space and time. It is not known what mechanisms create the enhanced plasma wave activity that leads to these radar returns. During this project we observed several such events using high time-resolution radar data and auroral imaging, revealing the small-scale and dynamic nature of the auroral structures that correspond with these radar returns. These detailed observations provided insight into the generation mechanisms, constraining potential theories to those that can explain the rapid time and altitude variability of the wave activity. There were several other additional outcomes regarding diffuse auroral structures and meteors. The diffuse and pulsating auroral structures observed were found to be consistent with pitch-angle scattering of 8 to 12 keV electrons by chorus waves. Meteors that we observed in the imagers were also detected by the radar, which allowed us to determine the full 3-dimensional velocity vector for each meteor. These combined radar and optical observations also provide two independent methods for determining meteoroid mass, which can significantly constrain the errors in estimating the total mass influx into the upper atmosphere.

Both the PI and Co-PI are young researchers who have gained valuable data collection and analysis skills through this project, as well as an expanding research interest area from which to launch new projects. In addition, the quality and volume of data collected are paramount in setting up the infrastructure needed for student involvement and training. These data can be used by students to study the auroral structure and occurrence in a statistical fashion as well as meteors in the imager and radar data. The Co-PI (M. Samara) is adjoint faculty at the University of Texas at San Antonio (UTSA). Results from these observations were used to demonstrate the structure and dynamics of the ionosphere in a graduate level ionospheric physics class that she developed and taught in the winter of 2010. Additionally, she has presented auroral movies taken during our campaigns at the "Expanding Your Horizons in Science and Mathematics" conference led by UTSA (January 2010 and February 2011), which is a hands on workshop for girls in grades 6 through 8.
